title: How to Make Organza Flowers

methods.name: Making a Flower with Individual Petals

steps.headline: Purchase silk or synthetic organza in any color.
steps.description: Choose 1 color or buy several shades of a color in order to make a realistic flower. For example, to make a red organza flower, choose a deep red, a lighter red, and a pale red. The slight color variation will make your flower look more natural.You might find organdie or organdy for sale near the organza. Don't use this for your flowers because it's made of cotton, which won't curl like organza. The amount of fabric you need depends on the size of your flowers and how many layers you use.

steps.headline: Cut out 2 or 3 circular templates in different widths.
steps.description: Get out a large piece of cardboard and find a plate or glass that's as wide as you want to make the flower. Set it on the cardboard. Trace around the side of the plate or glass to make a circle and cut it out. Then, make another 1 or 2 templates that are each ⁄2 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) smaller.For example, make 1 circle template that's 5 inches (13 cm) in diameter, 1 template that's 4 inches (10 cm), and a template that's 3 inches (7.6 cm).

steps.headline: Lay the templates on the fabric and cut at least 5 or 6 fabric circles.
steps.description: Spread your organza on a flat surface and place the templates on the fabric. Run fabric chalk or a pencil around each circle. Then, cut out the circles. Make as many circles in as many sizes as you like.Tip: Sort the fabric circles based on their size. This makes it easier to quickly assemble your flowers. Keep in mind that more layers make a fuller flower. For example, use around a dozen circles to make a very full flower.

steps.headline: Hold the edge of a fabric circle above a candle flame to singe it.
steps.description: To make the edges of your flower petals curl a little, light a candle and position an organza circle ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) above the flame. Hold it just close enough that the heat melts the edge of the fabric. Slowly rotate the circle to quickly singe all around the fabric edge.Repeat this for every petal to give them realistic texture. Set a glass of water near your work surface so you can quickly extinguish fabric if it catches on fire.

steps.headline: Stack your curled layers from largest to smallest.
steps.description: To assemble an organza flower, place a few of the largest circles on your work surface. Then, set 2 or 3 slightly smaller circles on them. Finish your flower by putting a few of the smallest circles on top.To make the flower look more realistic, shift some of the circles so they're slightly off-center.

steps.headline: Thread a needle and sew through the center to hold the flower in place.
steps.description: Use thread that matches the color of your fabric and insert the needle through the bottom of the flower. Pull the needle up through the center of the layers and bring the needle back down through the center. Continue sewing back and forth to make stitches that secure the flower.If you don't want to sew the flower, secure each layer in place with hot glue. Use caution when working with the hot glue so you don't burn yourself.

steps.headline: Tie the thread and trim the tail.
steps.description: Cut the thread tail close to the knot so it doesn't hang below the flower. Then, you can glue or sew small beads onto the center of the flower if you want to hide the stitches. Glue a small felt circle onto the bottom of the flower if you want to make a flat base for it.

steps.headline: Cut a strip of organza so it's 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10.2 cm) wide.
steps.description: Unroll organza fabric in any color and cut a piece that's at least 12 inches (30 cm) long and 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10.2 cm) wide. For a flower that's about 5 inches (13 cm) across, use the entire length of the fabric bolt which is usually around 40 inches (100 cm) long.Tip: This is a great project for using up leftover organza fabric. You could even use old organza curtains instead of buying new fabric.

steps.headline: Fold the strip of fabric into a rectangle.
steps.description: Fold 1 end of the fabric onto the opposite end so the strip is half its original length. Then, fold the folded edge over to the opposite end. Keep folding the fabric until you have a rectangle that's around 2 inches (5.1 cm) across.Folding the fabric allows you to cut the petals quickly.

steps.headline: Cut the top of the folded fabric to make a curved edge.
steps.description: Hold the folded fabric and use scissors to cut a curve along the top. Discard the fabric scraps and unfold the fabric strip to see the scalloped edge you just cut.Don't cut the bottom of the fabric or you'll have trouble holding onto the flower when you shape it.

steps.headline: Hold the scalloped edges over a candle flame if you want to curl the petals.
steps.description: Light a small candle and carefully hold just the curved edge of the fabric ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) above the flame. It only takes a second for the heat from the candle to singe the organza, so keep moving the scalloped edge over the flame until you've worked across the whole strip of fabric.If you aren't trying to create realistic petals, skip this step.

steps.headline: Fold the strip of fabric in half crosswise and thread a needle.
steps.description: Lay out the scalloped strip of organza. Take 1 end of the fabric and fold it so it's almost lined up with the opposite end. Then, thread a needle with thread that matches the color of the organza and tie a knot in the end.To give the flower a realistic look, don't line up the scallops perfectly. Instead, shift the top of the fabric so it overlaps the bottom scallops.

steps.headline: Work a running stitch across the bottom of the folded fabric strip.
steps.description: Insert the needle at the end of the strip so it goes through both layers of fabric. Leave about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) of space and push the needle back down through the fabric. Make a stitch back up through the fabric and leave another gap. Continue making the running stitch until you reach the folded end of the fabric.The running stitch is also called the basting stitch.

steps.headline: Pull the thread to gather the flower and sew the bottom of the flower.
steps.description: Once you've stitched to the end of the fabric strip, pull the thread gently. As you pull, the fabric will ruffle and gather. Bring the ends of the flower together and insert your needle into the other fabric end. Sew back and forth across the bottom of the flower so the layers stay in place.

steps.headline: Cut the thread and trim the excess to finish your flower.
steps.description: Cut the thread tail close to the knot so you don't see it trailing under the base of the flower. If you plan on attaching the flowers to other decorations, glue a small felt circle to the bottom of the flower. This gives you a base to attach to the other crafts.
